formula.string: System-Design, Web Dev, NuxtJS, Kubernetes, Docker

text.content: This article showcases one of the possible ways to deploy your NuxtJS or any similar application on the Google Kubernetes platform

rich_text.plain_text: This article showcases one of the possible ways to deploy your NuxtJS or any similar application on the Google Kubernetes platform

text.content: Deploying a NuxtJS application to a Kubernetes Cluster in Cloud

title.plain_text: Deploying a NuxtJS application to a Kubernetes Cluster in Cloud

text.content: If you have been following my series on creating a Personal Website, you might think this is insane! We haven't even written a single line of code for our website, and we are already deploying it to internet!! Hold your horses!

rich_text.plain_text: If you have been following my series on creating a Personal Website, you might think this is insane! We haven't even written a single line of code for our website, and we are already deploying it to internet!! Hold your horses!

text.content: I know this is uncommon. But believe me, this will help you to develop a more reliable and stable codebase. In addition, this article will help you deploy a web application(whether it's a full-fledged Portfolio website or just a shabby page with Grandma quotes) to a Kubernetes Cluster in Cloud(In this case, GCP).

rich_text.plain_text: I know this is uncommon. But believe me, this will help you to develop a more reliable and stable codebase. In addition, this article will help you deploy a web application(whether it's a full-fledged Portfolio website or just a shabby page with Grandma quotes) to a Kubernetes Cluster in Cloud(In this case, GCP).

text.content: : Even after using containerization of application, you might still face issues where the web app works perfectly in Dev environment but has issues in prod. These issues might accumulate over numerous commits. Detecting them early makes our life easier.

text.content: : It's impossible to share your code with your peers for review. But they can always suggest improvements by visiting your deployed website. I have received reviews and incorporated them to improve the user experience.

text.content: I won't go into many details here, but Kubernetes is a container orchestration framework. According to an official quote

rich_text.plain_text: I won't go into many details here, but Kubernetes is a container orchestration framework. According to an official quote

text.content: Kubernetes is a portable, extensible, open-source platform for managing containerized workloads and services that facilitates both declarative configuration and automation. It has a large, rapidly growing ecosystem. Kubernetes services, support, and tools are widely available.

rich_text.plain_text: Kubernetes is a portable, extensible, open-source platform for managing containerized workloads and services that facilitates both declarative configuration and automation. It has a large, rapidly growing ecosystem. Kubernetes services, support, and tools are widely available.

text.content: Here we'll use the native Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) Provided by Google Cloud Platform (GCP)  to deploy our nuxt application.

text.content: Type: Depends on your requirements and budget. If you are low on budget, select zone instead of the region. You are trading redundancy for cost.

text.content: : You can choose E2-Medium (2 vCPU, 4 GB Ram). This gives you a total of 4vCPU and 8 GB Ram.

text.content: Containers, by definition, are stateless and ephemeral. Hence, to store persistent data, you need persistent storage, which the containers can then connect to store data. You can create a standard PV(persistent volume). But here, I'll create a better, solid-state drive for improved performance.

rich_text.plain_text: Containers, by definition, are stateless and ephemeral. Hence, to store persistent data, you need persistent storage, which the containers can then connect to store data. You can create a standard PV(persistent volume). But here, I'll create a better, solid-state drive for improved performance.

text.content: 1. First, you need to create a Volume class

rich_text.plain_text: 1. First, you need to create a Volume class

text.content:
# ssd-storageclass.yaml
apiVersion: storage.k8s.io/v1
kind: StorageClass
metadata:
  name: solid-state
provisioner: kubernetes.io/gce-pd
parameters:
  type: pd-ssd

rich_text.plain_text:
# ssd-storageclass.yaml
apiVersion: storage.k8s.io/v1
kind: StorageClass
metadata:
  name: solid-state
provisioner: kubernetes.io/gce-pd
parameters:
  type: pd-ssd

text.content: 2. Then, you can create a PV Claim.

rich_text.plain_text: 2. Then, you can create a PV Claim.

text.content:
# PersistentVolumeClaim.yml
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  name: limosyn-com-pv-claim
spec:
  storageClassName: solid-state
  accessModes:
  - ReadWriteOnce
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 10Gi

rich_text.plain_text:
# PersistentVolumeClaim.yml
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  name: limosyn-com-pv-claim
spec:
  storageClassName: solid-state
  accessModes:
  - ReadWriteOnce
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 10Gi

text.content: Great! We need to setup Github Actions to directly build and deploy our application from the Repository(CI/CD).

rich_text.plain_text: Great! We need to setup Github Actions to directly build and deploy our application from the Repository(CI/CD).

text.content: as your version control, you can use GitHub actions to setup a CI/CD workflow that will directly deploy your application to production. GitHub Actions has good integration with the GKE platform.

rich_text.plain_text: as your version control, you can use GitHub actions to setup a CI/CD workflow that will directly deploy your application to production. GitHub Actions has good integration with the GKE platform.

text.content: Make sure you have a GCP account and have already setup a cluster following the steps in the previous section.

rich_text.plain_text: Make sure you have a GCP account and have already setup a cluster following the steps in the previous section.

text.content: Get a service account with proper access to GKE.

rich_text.plain_text: Get a service account with proper access to GKE.

text.content: Now you need to add four important files. You can add them manually, but I suggest using GitHub itself to add them. These files are:

rich_text.plain_text: Now you need to add four important files. You can add them manually, but I suggest using GitHub itself to add them. These files are:

text.content: : Main configuration used by GitHub to access your Kubernetes cluster and deploy. It also publishes the generated Image to google's Container Registry.

rich_text.plain_text: : Main configuration used by GitHub to access your Kubernetes cluster and deploy. It also publishes the generated Image to google's Container Registry.

rich_text.plain_text: : Has deployment information such as the number of replicas, deployment strategy, to name a few.

rich_text.plain_text: : Has information required to expose your deployed service to the internet or within your cluster.

text.content: First of all, let's setup a

rich_text.plain_text: First of all, let's setup a

text.content: which will be used by GA to generate the application image. This image would then be pushed to Google Container Registry.

rich_text.plain_text: which will be used by GA to generate the application image. This image would then be pushed to Google Container Registry.

text.content:
#Dockerfile

FROM node:latest as build-stage
RUN apt update -y && apt upgrade -y
WORKDIR /app
COPY package.json yarn.lock ./
RUN yarn install
COPY ./ .
EXPOSE 3000
ENV HOST=0.0.0.0
ENV PORT=3000
RUN yarn build
CMD ["yarn", "start"]

rich_text.plain_text:
#Dockerfile

FROM node:latest as build-stage
RUN apt update -y && apt upgrade -y
WORKDIR /app
COPY package.json yarn.lock ./
RUN yarn install
COPY ./ .
EXPOSE 3000
ENV HOST=0.0.0.0
ENV PORT=3000
RUN yarn build
CMD ["yarn", "start"]

rich_text.plain_text: is the content of your service account

text.content: files. For reference, they can be:

rich_text.plain_text: files. For reference, they can be:

text.content:
# deployment.yml

apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: nuxt-frontend
  namespace: "default"
spec:
  replicas: 2
  strategy:
    type: RollingUpdate
    rollingUpdate:
      maxSurge: 1
      maxUnavailable: 0
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: nuxt-frontend
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: nuxt-frontend
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: app
        image: gcr.io/PROJECT_ID/IMAGE:TAG
        imagePullPolicy: Always
        ports:
        - containerPort: 3000
        livenessProbe:
          tcpSocket:
            port: 3000
          initialDelaySeconds: 10
          timeoutSeconds: 5
          periodSeconds: 30
        readinessProbe:
          tcpSocket:
            port: 3000
          initialDelaySeconds: 30
          timeoutSeconds: 5
          periodSeconds: 30

rich_text.plain_text:
# deployment.yml

apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: nuxt-frontend
  namespace: "default"
spec:
  replicas: 2
  strategy:
    type: RollingUpdate
    rollingUpdate:
      maxSurge: 1
      maxUnavailable: 0
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: nuxt-frontend
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: nuxt-frontend
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: app
        image: gcr.io/PROJECT_ID/IMAGE:TAG
        imagePullPolicy: Always
        ports:
        - containerPort: 3000
        livenessProbe:
          tcpSocket:
            port: 3000
          initialDelaySeconds: 10
          timeoutSeconds: 5
          periodSeconds: 30
        readinessProbe:
          tcpSocket:
            port: 3000
          initialDelaySeconds: 30
          timeoutSeconds: 5
          periodSeconds: 30

text.content:
# service.yml

apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: nuxt-frontend
  namespace: default
  labels:
    app: nuxt-frontend
    tier: frontend
spec:
  ports:
  - protocol: TCP
    port: 80
    targetPort: 3000
  selector:
    app: nuxt-frontend
  type: LoadBalancer

rich_text.plain_text:
# service.yml

apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: nuxt-frontend
  namespace: default
  labels:
    app: nuxt-frontend
    tier: frontend
spec:
  ports:
  - protocol: TCP
    port: 80
    targetPort: 3000
  selector:
    app: nuxt-frontend
  type: LoadBalancer

text.content:
# kustomization.yml

apiVersion: kustomize.config.k8s.io/v1beta1
kind: Kustomization

resources:
  - .github/service.yaml
  - .github/deployment.yaml

rich_text.plain_text:
# kustomization.yml

apiVersion: kustomize.config.k8s.io/v1beta1
kind: Kustomization

resources:
  - .github/service.yaml
  - .github/deployment.yaml

text.content: Provided you did everything right, the next time you push changes to your repository, GitHub actions will deploy your application to your Kubernetes Cluster.

rich_text.plain_text: Provided you did everything right, the next time you push changes to your repository, GitHub actions will deploy your application to your Kubernetes Cluster.

text.content: You should be able to see the created deployments.

text.content: This guide can be used to deploy all types of basic applications. Of course, there will be adaptations, but the soul would remain the same.✌?
